[[SC of New York]] |retired= |medaltemplates= {{MedalCountry| [[United States]]}} {{MedalSport | Men's [[Figure skating]]}} {{MedalCompetition|[[North American Figure Skating Championships|North American Championships]]}} {{MedalSilver|[[1939 North American Figure Skating Championships|1939 Toronto]]|[[1939 North American Figure Skating Championships|Men's singles]]}} {{MedalSilver|[[1935 North American Figure Skating Championships|1935 Montreal]]|[[1935 North American Figure Skating Championships|Men's singles]]}} {{MedalBronze|[[1933 North American Figure Skating Championships|1933 New York]]|[[1933 North American Figure Skating Championships|Men's singles]]}} }} '''Robin Huntington Lee''' (December 2, 1919 in [[Saint Paul, Minnesota]] â October 8, 1997 in [[Minneapolis]]) was an [[United States|American]] [[figure skater]]. He was the 1935-1939 [[United States Figure Skating Championships|U.S. national champion]]. At age 12, he became the youngest skater to win the junior national title.{{cite news | url = http://www.nytimes.com/1997/10/14/sports/robin-lee-77-figure-skating-champion.html | title = Robin Lee, 77, Figure Skating Champion | publisher = [[New York Times]] | date = October 14, 1997 | accessdate = October 29, 2009}} At the [[1935 United States Figure Skating Championships]], at the age of 15,{{cite news | url =http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,770632,00.html | title = Sport: Figures in Chicago | publisher = [[TIME]] | date = February 22, 1937 | accessdate = October 29, 2009}}{{cite news | url = http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,748489-2,00.html | title = Sport: Snow & Ice | publisher = [[TIME]] | date = February 18, 1935| accessdate = October 29, 2009}} he became the first and, as of 2008, the only skater to defeat a seven time national champion in the United States. Lee represented the [[United States at the 1936 Winter Olympics]], where he placed 12th. He was selected to compete at the [[1940 Winter Olympics]], which were canceled due to [[World War II]]. During the War, Lee served in the [[U.S. Navy]].{{cite news |url = http://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1338&dat=19460422&id=WiQVAAAAIBAJ&sjid=gPUDAAAAIBAJ&pg=7124,4709154 | title = Skating Expert With Ice Cycles Is Ex-Champion | publisher = [[Spokane Daily Chronicle]] | date = April 22, 1946 | accessdate = October 29, 2009}} After the War, Lee skated professionally in ice shows and worked as a coach. Lee was inducted into the [[U.S. Figure Skating Hall of Fame]] in 1995. He attended [[Erasmus Hall High School]]. ==Competitive highlights== {| class="wikitable" |- !
